iati-activity.title: Dar Al Athar Al-Islamiyah
iati-activity.description: The project objectives are to train Kuwaitis to become professional museum and laboratories employees in the preservation and display of selected artefacts from the Dar Al-Athar Al-Islamiyyah collection at the Kuwait National Museum.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. No. of Kuwaiti conservators of wood and stone artefacts (organic). 2. No. of Kuwaiti conservators of metal artefacts (non-organic). 3. No. of Kuwaiti conservators of ivory artefacts. 4. No. of Kuwaiti trainees to be installers for museum exhibitions selected. 5. No. of new Kuwaiti museum administrators. 6. No. of trained Kuwaiti museum teachers 7. No. of new Kuwaiti engineers for design and supervision 8. No. of trained Kuwaiti museum graphic designers.

baseline.comment: 1. There are no Kuwaiti conservators of wood and stone artefacts (organic). 2. There are no Kuwaiti conservators of metal artefacts (non-organic). 3. There are no Kuwaiti conservators of ivory artefacts. 4. There are no Kuwaiti Museum Installers for museum exhibitions. 5. No trained Kuwaiti museum administrators 6. No trained Kuwaiti museum teachers 7. Only 6 Kuwaiti Engineers for design and supervision 8. No trained Kuwaiti graphic designers.

target.comment:
Output 1: 1. Assist Kuwaiti Authorities to undertake conservation work on the collection of the museum and undertake any other work in connection with the conservation of the collection. - Provide training and advise to assistant conservators in the conservation work on the collection of the museum - Liase with other curatorial staff - Manage the conservation laboratories - Train and implement a program of environmental monitoring - Train and implement a Pest management programme - Train the strategies for the ‘house-keeping’ of the collection in the storage and on display - Outsource and manage external specialized expertize. 2. Assist Kuwaiti Authorities to undertake conservation work on the collection of the museum and undertake any other work in connection with the conservation of the collection Provide training and advise to assistant conservators in the conservation work on the collection of the museum. - Liaise with other curatorial staff - Undertake any other tasks pertaining to the consultancy deemed appropriate by DAI and UNDP. 3. Assist Kuwaiti Authorities to undertake conservation work on the collection of the museum and undertake any other work in connection with the conservation of the collection. - Provide training and advise to assistant conservators in the conservation work on the collection of the museum - Liaise with other curatorial staff - Undertake any other tasks pertaining to the consultancy deemed appropriate by DAI and UNDP. 4. Assist Kuwaiti Authorities to undertake conservation work on the collection of the museum and undertake any other work in connection with the conservation of the collection. - Provide training and advise to assistant conservators in the conservation work on the collection of the museum - Liaise with other curatorial staff - Undertake any other tasks pertaining to the consultancy deemed appropriate by DAI and UNDP.
Output 2: - Provide training in preparing educational programs, such as pottery, painting and other

actual.comment:
Output 1: 1. - Trainees Kuwaiti assistant conservators were involved in conservation work on the collection. - Trainees Kuwaiti assistant conservators were involved in management for the conservation laboratories, in ‘house keeping’ of the collection and in the implementation of Pest management programme. - Trainees Kuwaiti assistant conservators were involved in environmental monitoring of the ACC galleries. 2. - Trainees Kuwaiti assistant conservators were involved in conservation work on the collection. - Trainees Kuwaiti assistant conservators were involved in management for the conservation laboratories, in ‘house keeping’ of the collection and in the implementation of Pest management programme. - Trainees Kuwaiti assistant conservators were involved in environmental monitoring of the ACC galleries. 3. - Trainees Kuwaiti assistant conservators were involved in conservation work on the collection. - Trainees Kuwaiti assistant conservators were involved in management for the conservation laboratories, in ‘house keeping’ of the collection and in the implementation of Pest management programme. - Trainees Kuwaiti assistant conservators were involved in environmental monitoring of the ACC galleries. 4. Not activated.
Output 2: - Trainees Kuwaiti local DAI staff involved in the development of Educational strategies for the cultural institution.
Output 3: - Trainees Kuwaiti architects/engineers were involved in the tender procedure for KNM - Trainees Kuwaiti architects/engineers were involved in the review of the contractors offer for the tender - Trainees Kuwaiti architects/engineers were involved in technical meeting while decisions were taken - Trainees Kuwaiti architects/engineers were involved in the supervision of the maintenance works at the ACC.
Output 4: Not activated.
New Output 1: Not activated.
New Output 2: Not activated.
New Output 3: Not activated.

target.comment: Output 1: 1 - Assist Kuwaiti Authorities to undertake conservation work on the collection of the museum and undertake any other work in connection with the conservation of the collection - Provide training and advise to assistant conservators in the conservation work on the collection of the museum - liaise with other curatorial staff - Manage the conservation laboratories - Train and implement a program of environmental monitoring - Train and implement a Pest management programme - Train the strategies for the ‘house-keeping’ of the collection in the storage and on display - Outsource and manage external specialized expertize - Train and implement and carry out a programme of inhouse conservation (approx.. 33.000 objects) - Support the expert for the display of the artefacts in the museum - Undertake any other tasks pertaining to the consultancy deemed appropriate by DAI and UNDP. 2 - Assist Kuwaiti Authorities to undertake conservation work on the collection of the museum and undertake any other work in connection with the conservation of the collection. - Provide training and advise to assistant conservators in the conservation work on the collection of the museum - liaise with other curatorial staff - Undertake any other tasks pertaining to the consultancy deemed appropriate by DAI and UNDP. 3 - Assist Kuwaiti Authorities to undertake conservation work on the collection of the museum and undertake any other work in connection with the conservation of the collection. - Provide training and advise to assistant conservators in the conservation work on the collection of the museum - Liaise with other curatorial staff - Undertake any other tasks pertaining to the consultancy deemed appropriate by DAI and UNDP. 4. Assist Kuwaiti Authorities to undertake conservation work on the collection of the museum and undertake any other work in connection with the conservation of the collection. - Provide training and advise to assistant conservators in the conservation work

actual.comment: Output 1: Under guidance 3 Kuwaiti trainees have been involved with a diverse number of projects and in the normal processes involved in the care of the collection. All have been working on the continued programme of cleaning objects using the Q-switch Nd:YAG laser. Output 2: The expert mission terminated in the second quarter of 2014. DAI is now implementing the programs developed with the expert. As a result of the UNDP expert's work with the Dar al-Athar al-Islamiyyah’s education team, the DAI is currently offering four new programmes and five existing programmes. The new programmes extend DAI reach from age 6 to adult to age 18 months to adult and offer new opportunities for primary students in Kuwait to benefit from aspects of the museum experience in their own classrooms. The expanded programmes improve the interaction between the DAI, DAI museum educators and the participants, making the programmes more challenging and more rewarding. The DAI Education program coordinator was asked to briefly outline the major impacts that the UNDP-supported training session added to the program. Here are the results: 1. The DAI education team was already implementing some programmes quite well. However DAI didn’t know why they worked, making the chances of attaining the level of success in other programmes a matter of luck. By providing DAI with education theory and application tools, the Program now understand why some things work and others don’t and are able to build from there. 2. The DAI education team had ideas for additional programmes, but really had no idea how to implement them. For example, most museums in the West offer programmes for children starting at 18 months and we recognized that that was important. But, what do you do with a toddler in a museum and what can you expect when working with toddlers? The expert helped DAI construct the necessary programmes (including the one for toddlers) by having DAI team work through the skills, social skills and abilities

iati-activity.title: Traffic Strategy
iati-activity.description: Improve planning and design process; cost of road accidents to the community; optimize movement of people and goods; enhance public transport service; strength law enforcement; contribute to climate change.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
Output 1: - Centralized / integrated electronic information system developed. - Capacity of GDT enhanced. - Information – specific cadres selected and trained.
Output 2: - Modern blackspot and road safety system established. - Accident investigation procedures enhanced. - Safety conscious - road design system established. - Specialised cadres in blackspot and road safety selected and trained.
Output 3: - Appropriate implementation process of the approved NTTS established nationwide. - Progress achieved toward implementation of the required institutional reform and staff training. - Centres of Excellence and new units established within the GDT. - Link with the private sector and stakeholders established to tackle traffic problems. - M & E system established.

baseline.comment:
Output 1: - No centralized / integrated electronic information system available. - Inadequate capacity of the GDT to provide traffic-related services for the stakeholders. - Lack of information expertise.
Output 2: - Absence of modern blackspot and road safety system. - Unavailability of modern accident investigation procedures. - Lack of accident documentations. - Shortage of specialised skills in blackspot and road safety. - Unavailability of safety conscious- road design system.
Output 3: - Lack of implementation of the Government approved NTTS by relevant Ministries. - Slow progress toward implementation of the required institutional reform to enhance capacity and optimize the use of resources. - Lack of efficient sector-specific skills. - Unavailability of equipment, software, systems, devices and guidelines.

target.comment:
Output 1: - Fully operational system in place and linked with relevant GDT Directorates - Protocol to download electronic data and collect data from other sources established - User manual and guidelines developed and disseminated to relevant GDT staff - Project website established and access provided to decision makers, practitioners and stakeholders - Operation police in all Governorates provided with iPAD for data collection - Relevant GDT Directorates provided with equipment and socialized software, and institutional management enhanced - 100 police officers, engineers and technician trained on the use of the system.
Output 2: - Uniform blackspot and road safety system in use in the 6 Governorates - National blackspot guidelines developed and disseminated within the GDT and for relevant Ministries - Accident investigation guidelines developed and disseminated within the GDT and General Directorate of Investigation - Identification and treatment of 50 blackspots locations per annum - Reduction of road traffic fatalities to below 460 - Reduction of fatality rate per 100,000 populations to below 14 - 60 National cadres trained in use of the system.
Output 3: - Efficient system established with support of the Supreme Traffic Council and Deputy Ministers to ensure implementation of the NTTS by relevant Ministries - Capacity of the GDT enhanced, and new transport authority approved by the National Assembly in July 2014 and established by the Government in October 2014 - Organisational structures developed for the new Centres of Excellence and equipment and devises provided on time - Guidelines in traffic operations, awareness and driving license developed and disseminated - 2 International workshops for training of the national cadres in areas which are not available nationally addressed by the Ministers and attended by over 450 people - 80 women trained in specialized areas - Joint programs with the stakeholders, counterparts and private sector conducted - M & E

actual.comment: All activities have been transferred to 2015 where the new project document indicates the project period 2015-2016.

target.comment:
Output 1: - Fully operational system in place and linked with relevant GDT Directorates - Protocol to download electronic data and collect data from various sources established - User manual and guidelines developed and disseminated to relevant GDT staff - Project website established and access provided to decision makers, practitioners and stakeholders - Operation police in all Governorates provided with iPAD for data collection - Relevant GDT Directorates provided with equipment and socialized software, and institutional management enhanced - 100 police officers, engineers and technician trained on the use of the system.
Output 2: - Uniform blackspot and road safety system in use in the 6 Governorates - National blackspot guidelines developed and disseminated within the GDT and for relevant Ministries - Accident investigation guidelines developed and disseminated within the GDT and General Directorate of Investigation - Identification and treatment of 50 blackspots locations per annum - Reduction of road traffic fatalities to below 460 - Reduction of fatality rate per 100,000 populations to below 14 - 160 National cadres trained in use of the system.
Output 3: - Efficient system established with support of the Supreme Traffic Council and Deputy Ministers to ensure implementation of the NTTS by relevant Ministries - Capacity of the GDT enhanced, and new transport authority approved by the National Assembly in July 2014 and established by the Government in October 2014, and operational support provided during 2015 - Organisational structures developed for the new Centres of Excellence and equipment and devises provided on time - Guidelines in traffic operations, awareness and driving license developed and disseminated - 2 International workshops for training of the national cadres in areas which are not available nationally addressed by the Ministers and attended by over 450 people - 80 women trained in specialized areas - Joint programs with the stakeholders, c

actual.comment:
Output 1: - Continuation of building the NTIS system. - Continuation of assessment of traffic congestion and plotting of GIS map data – ongoing task. - Coordination with General Directorate of Traffic and relevant departments for information system design, development and interfacing of relevant data - ongoing task. - Installation of GIS hardware and software in new Project Office with the networking datasets – ongoing task. - Scanning of GIS / AutoCAD maps received from Ministry of Electricity and Water (MEW) is in progress for identifying electricity poles location in Kuwait which will be used in the “Out of the Box” software system – ongoing task. - ArcGIS Personal Geodatabase for electricity poles location is under progress from the AutoCAD maps - ongoing task. - Settlements of TRL Team in Strategy Project office at GDT HQ. - Identification of required software, system and information for the successful bidder of the “Out of the Box” software. - Maps scanning and plotting of important landmarks by using A0 scanner – ongoing task. - Continuation of the Project Team in the development of Accidents, Traffic, Offences and other relevant information and system using the available resources. - Project Initiation Meeting with TRL team Conducted on 2nd Aug 2015 on the Project overview. - Accident Reporting Form (ARF) review discussion meeting with TRL team on 11 Aug 2015, TRL provided a live demo of the iMAAP system to MOI & UNDP and demonstrated various features of iMAAP. - Accident Reporting Form has been completed by TRL as per the planned activities and approved by GDT with slight modifications. - Various progress meetings have been conducted by Project Team and Project coordinators, GDT-MOI as mentioned below.
Output 2: - Continuation of assessment of traffic congestion and preparation of GIS maps – ongoing task. - Continuation of study of black spot data. - Coordination with General Directorate of Traffic and relevant departments for database design & development

target.comment: 1) Technical Studies Conducted and Published/Produced: 1. A Standardization Study of a computer based dyslexia screener (Kuwait Dyslexia Association). 2. Inclusion in Kuwait and Inclusive Educational Schools Project (Centre for Child Evaluation & Teaching). 3. Strategic Plan for Kuwait Society for Learning Difference (Kuwait Society for Learning Difference). 4. Strategic Plan for Kuwait Autism Centre (Kuwait Autism Centre). 5. A Study to establish a Disability Information Centre at the Ministry of Education (Ministry of Education). 6. A Study for a Curriculum Design for Slow Learners at Secondary School Level at the Ministry of Education (Ministry of Education). 7. Study of Violence Against children and anti-bullying efforts in Kuwait (Kuwait Association for the Protection of Children). 8. Criteria for the identification of Movement and Hearing Disabilities in Kuwait (Public Authority of the Disabled). 9. Criteria for the identification of Hearing Disabilities in Kuwait (Public Authority of the Disabled). 10. Kuwait National Prize for Best Teachers in Special Education (Kuwait Association for Learning Difference). 2) Nationally Standardized Tests produced: 1. Arabic Diagnostic Placement Tests (Grade 1 till 9) for the assessment of Learning Disabilities (Centre for Child Evaluation & Teaching). 2. Arabic Computer based Learning Disabilities Screener (Centre for Child Evaluation & Teaching). 3. Arabic IPhone Application for the identification of At Risk individuals of Dyslexia (Kuwait Dyslexia Association). 3) Awareness Activities: 1. Participated in and gave a Key note speech at Al Nibras Second Spring Conference on the Inclusion of Persons with Disabilities (March 2011). 2. Participated and sponsored the International Day for the Disabled (December 3rd 2011, 2012 and 2013). 3. Participated and co-sponsored First and Second International Conferences on Learning Challenges: LDs and AD(H)D in 2011 and 2013. 4) Publications Produced and Printed 1

actual.comment:
1. Currently in the process of populating the model with emissions inventories of local industry and area sources to provide the necessary data required for the hotspot modeling. We completed West Shuaiba and focusing on the Subhan area.
2.Software procured and currently being configured and populated for KEPA use. It is operational now.
3. Provide training on system operations. Training was provided during the workshop and will be conducted on the final version in December 2014

iati-activity.title: Women Economic Empowerment Pro
iati-activity.description: Economic Empowerment of Kuwaiti Women project uses the Enterprise Development Programme three components:(1) Institutional Capacity building; (2) Implementation of the Enterprise Creation Programme; (3) Implementation of the Enterprise Growth Programme.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: - Number of awareness building activities conducted. - Establishment of enterprise development units (EDUs)

baseline.comment: - Relatively low knowledge on the process of enterprise development - No institutional capacity to provide a holistic service package to budding entrepreneurs. Also, low level of entrepreneurial and business culture.

target.comment: • The project ran a holistic package of enterprise development tools and techniques in order to support Kuwaiti women to reach their individual potential as successful entrepreneurs. The Enterprise Development & Investment Promotion Program of the United Nations Industrial Development Organization (UNIDO) was delivered as it aims at assisting potential entrepreneurs transform their ideas into existing businesses through a modality called “Enterprise Creation” and at the same time assist entrepreneurs with existing businesses to grow and expand their businesses (Enterprise growth). • The following capacity building programs where conducted: o Training of trainers for enterprise creation was held in Kuwait with a total of 17 MOSAL Staff. o Business Counselling was held in Bahrain with 4 MOSAL staff. The practical component of the Business Counselling was held in Kuwait with the participation of 6 MOSAL staff and 20 Kuwaiti women entrepreneurs. • The first women business incubator in Kuwait and the Gulf region was launched in February 2013 and hosts 38 women. The process includes modifying a spacious building to accommodate an excellent business incubator. The businesses range from software applications and media to traditional crafts and catering. The Incubator provides the physical infrastructure required to establish a small business and supports the development of the technical skills and expertise the entrepreneurs will need to launch, manage and develop sustainable businesses. • A media campaign was conducted which involved a press conference, several TV interviews, and newspaper articles spread awareness about the incubator and gained the attention of various stakeholders • Several specialized trainings and seminars by experts in their fields were carried out to all parties, locally and regionally, to develop the required entrepreneurial skills of the women entrepreneurs, ToT and Business Counselling, as well as many other ongoing counselling activities. T

actual.comment: The project had completed all of its activities by 2013 but it was extended to 2014 to finalize all activities fully.

target.comment: Project is closed by end of 2014.

actual.comment: Project is operationally closed in 2015.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: 1. Relevant legal information is compiled, reviewed and presented in user-friendly format. 2. Relevant legal information is produced on CDs, radio messages, booklets, posted on the project website and disseminated. 3. Number of persons accessing legal information and the project website users. 4. Number and quality of press releases on gender in national and regional media enhanced. 5. Major activities (project roll-out conference and events) of the project are covered by the media and receive public attention. 6.Social media effectively used to spread messages and flag issues

baseline.comment: 1. Systematic compilation of legal information on laws and court rulings is incomplete or is not available. 2. Existing legal information is not user-friendly and not easily accessible. 3. Media does not have sufficient knowledge and or qualifications to report on gender-related issues. 4. Awareness of women’s legal rights among the general public not well developed.

target.comment: - Establish, launch and maintain the interactive website - TOT training (Legal professionals and Civil Society ) - Two training sessions on listening and counseling - Publications - Prepare a pool of skillful national trainers from the legal profession, the law enforcement bodies, the support mechanisms, the social workers and civil society on the key concepts on the international human/women’s rights and the legal empowerment. - Provide the participants practical tools and participatory approaches techniques which are tailored for the Kuwaiti legislative and legal system and to satisfy the audience needs and interest. - Develop a training manual that tailored for national trainers

actual.comment: - Warcati website established as www.wracati.org.The website provides legal information and access to legal knowledge and services to women and the public in Kuwait. It includes professional links, legislations, publications and studies to enhance the professional capacities of the legal and professional community in Kuwait. It receives queries through the hot line and the dedicated email. Answers will be posted through the FAQ on the women’s empowerment key pillars: Protection from violence against women; Economic empowerment; political and citizenship right; equality in family and marriage. The local ownership and the buy- in were ensured throughout the process of data collection and the construction of the website. For this purpose close consultations with the implementing partners and the legal professional community were prompted. All materials are gender sensitive, women’s rights responsive and meet the project objectives and the target groups needs and expectations. New smart WRACTI phone application was developed (iPhone and Android),

target.comment: Project was closed by end 2014.

actual.comment: Project was closed operationally in 2015.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
Output 1: 1. WRSC logo and branding available 2. Availability of a SC to advocate for and guide the development of the WRSC 3. Presence of a library on research and data on women in Kuwait 4. Amount of funds raised for constructing WRSC
Output 2: 1. Availability of an information system on women’s surveys and research 2. # of surveys incorporated in the WRSC database 3. # global indicators referenced by the WRSC data 4. Presence of an organizational structure for the WRSC 5. # of trainings planned by the WRSC 6. # of trainings conducted 7. # of individuals trained on the WRSC database 8. # of staff recruited to run the WRSC 9. # of WRSC trained on administration, information systems and gender mainstreaming tools 10. # new research on women in Kuwait commissioned 11. Availability of a training manual for the database.
Output 3: 1. # of workshops conducted 2. # of participants attending workshops 3. # of seminars held 4. Amount of funds raised for seminars 5. # of women’s CSOs and institutions participating in seminars

baseline.comment:
Output 1: 1. Lack of existence of center on research, statistics, indicators exclusively on women in Kuwait 2. Lack of effective mechanism for supporting women to access reliable information & accurate data
Output 2: 1. Lack of digital database on research, statistics, indicators on women in Kuwait and GCC 2. Lack of new and updated data and existence of duplicate information 3. Lack of staff capacity building and ability to identify and address gender in all data production phases
Output 3: 1. No women’s training centers in Kuwait.

target.comment: 1) RAISING AWARENESS AND BREAKING THE SILENCE ON SENSITIVE GENDER ISSUES IN THE REGION AND CREATING PUBLIC DEBATE/ DISCUSSION IN THE COMMUNITY. 2) BEING A ROLE MODEL TO FOLLOW. 3) CAPACITY BUILDING 4) ESTABLISHING A GENDER LIBRARY 5) USE OF SOCIAL MEDIA TO REACH OUT TO YOUTH ABOUT GENDER ISSUES 6) NATIONAL AND REGIONAL INTEREST OF PARTNERSHIP 7) PUBLICATIONS OUTREACH

actual.comment: 1) multiple requests from women Non Governmental Organizations and based on needs assessment surveys distributed among youth organizations within the academic arena, several lectures series were organized covering sensitive gender topics such as: violence against women, discrimination against women in the health sector, the CEDAW treaty, women and parliaments, the role of the media in empowering women and the rights of women nationals married to non Nationals. This led to raising awareness among the Kuwaiti society about the gender gaps and on the discrimination women go through in the Region. - Recommendations from the participants of these conferences included: the Women’s Research and Studies Center to take the lead in organizing media and leadership trainings locally and regionally. - Breaking the silence on the sensitive topic of “National women married to non Nationals” (through a roundtable discussion on the rights of these mothers/ spouses and their daily suffering) led to requests from different Civil Society Organizations in Kuwait to share the write up of the discussion and led to recommendations such as the Center to take the lead in a comparative Research paper on this topic. The 6 GCC Parliamentarians speakers committed to present the results of this research to their parliaments and to the Women Affairs at the Gulf Cooperation Council to try and change the laws. - Over 500 participants attended the 10 lectures/ conferences organized by the WRSC. - 10 Regional and international high profile speakers. - Media coverage (all local newspapers and TV). 2) The Women’s Research and Studies Center received requests from Iraq Country Office to share information on the Center in order to duplicate the same Center there - A request came also from a Sudanese Civil Society Organization to help them create a similar Center. 3) The quality of the WRSC trainings led to further requests from the trained Institutions to a longer collaboration - 20 workshops were organiz

target.comment: Project is finished by 2014. Project is closed operationally in 2015.

actual.comment: Project is finished by 2014. Project is closed operationally in 2015.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: - # of experts contracted to support national planning institutions and develop GSSCPD staff capacities - # of policies developed to support planning processes

target.comment: - Technical and human capacity of the GSSCPD developed to enable it to conduct its functions more effectively. - Upgrading GSSCPD’s internal control framework to ensure the synergy of all processes between all sectors - Ensure the smooth knowledge sharing and flow of information between all relevant parties.

actual.comment: - Recruitment of experts in different GSSCPD departments to support building the technical and human capacity. - New developed indicators of the NMRDP by recruited experts at GSSCPD. - Recruitment of experts in different government institutions to support development of the NMRDP projects. - Development of Marco and micro economic development models for future forecasting, the output of which was utilized in the development of the new NMRDP - The National framework for Youth development and engagement.

target.comment: - To Upgrading GSSCPD’S NDP PM&E systems and framework - To develop relevant technical staff’s skills in programme development, project management, strategic planning and M&E - Align Sectoral SP with the NMRDP towards accelerating the achievement of the MDGs and ensuring the national preparedness to implement the SDGs. - It was agreed to combine this project and CSB project in a new project document and new AWP with combining their budgets where the period of January - June 2015 was considered as a transition period.

actual.comment: - Developed a new plan for restructuring and reorganization of the GSSCPD to strategically improve efficiency, oversight, coordination and planning function. - Development of new SOPs - Signature of the new CPD/CPAP - It was agreed to combine this project and CSB project in a new project document and new AWP with combining their budgets where the period of January - June 2015 was considered as a transition period.

target.comment: GSSCPD has agreed to reactivate the project but with a revised project budget and AWP. actual.comment: In February 2014, UNDP received a request from SAB to reactivate the project, which was communicated to GSSCPD, who approved the project’s reactivation on May 2014.

actual.comment: In May 2015, UNDP received a request from SAB to Develop the ToR of RFP, which was communicated to GSSCPD, who approved the project’s new AWP. The ToR of RFP developed by UNDP advertisement of RFP started on 26 Nov 2015

iati-activity.title: Fostering Youth Resiliency in Kuwait
iati-activity.description: Based on the increasing incidence of violence amongst youth, this project is intended as a response to foster the resiliency of young people to encourage healthy lifestyles and reduce violence and risky activities.

document-link.title: 2013 Annual Progress Report - Fostering Youth Resiliency

iati-activity.title: Fostering Youth Resiliency in
iati-activity.description: To response to the increasing incidences of violence among school-age youth, with an ultimate goal of decreasing the dysfunctional behaviors,by encouraging more healthy lifestyles through self-awareness, and social skills enhancement.

iati-activity.title: Support to Public Authority of Manpower
iati-activity.description: PAM is partnering with UNDP, IOM& ILO to improve the labor conditions. This prog aims to support PAM to develop internal capacity in reporting on its own performance, on labor movement & on compliance with int'l labor standards.

iati-activity.title: Support to Public Authority of
iati-activity.description: PAM plans to improve the labour conditions and management system by analysing the demographic imbalance, making sound decision based on enhanced reporting mechanisms and upgrading its services quality for all economic and social actors.

transaction.disbursement-channel: Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account
Money is disbursed directly to the implementing institution and managed through a separate bank account

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Output 2.1: - Research programmes deliver data and knowledge that support evidence-based policy-making in PAM. - PAM has greater understanding of how non-market factors impact labour mobility in GoK and recommendations on how to address this. - # of adjustments to PAM procedures carried out to better align with labour market objectives, as per recommendations of report. Output 2.1: - GoK/PAM have new information available to further improve and/or expand the shelter - GoK/PAM have new skills and knowledge regarding shelter management - GoK/PAM exposed to best practices, lessons learned, and able to share information on shelter management - GoK/PAM informed of the operational and cost advantage of AVRR - Migrants are returned home voluntarily and provided with reintegration assistance. Output 3.1: No of Government, Employers and Workers representatives participated in a Standards training course in the ILO Training Centre in Turin. Output 3.2: No. of workshops held on the ratification and application of conventions 100, 111, 122, 129,187, and 189. Output 3.3: - International Labour Standards taken into account in court proceedings - No of trainers and judges from Kuwait trained in the ILO Training Centre in Turin - No of Information materials produced in Arabic Language. Output 3.4: - Number of capacity building workshops held on ILS implementation for parliamentarians. Output 4.1: 1- Number of Employees of Public Authority of Manpower leadership team trained. 2-Number of Enforcement Priorities established & Enforcement Plan developed. Output 4.2: - Assessment and recommendations completed Output 4.3: - Action Plan developed. Output 4.4: - Enforcement Plan implemented. Output 4.5: - National OSH Policy, Profile and Programme are produced. Output 4.6: - Number of training courses are conducted on basic OSH and risk assessment. Output 4.7: - No of OSH specialists receiving specialized training on the use of OSH equipment Output 4.8: - No of training courses for Wo

baseline.comment: Output 2.1: - No research capacity to support evidence-based policy development. - Limited knowledge of non-market drivers of labour mobility. - Labour Mobility Management Structures not fully aligned with GoK’s labour market and economic development goals. Output 2.2: - No available assessment of shelter - No. of workshops held on shelter management - No of study tours held on shelter management - No of technical roundtables on shelter management - No available information on feasibility of AVRR - No migrants assisted with AVRR. Output 3.1: Not enough training to Kuwait Government and social partners, on reporting. Output 3.2: - Insufficient capacity related to international labour standards. Output 3.3: - Not enough training on international Labour Standards. Output 3.4: - No capacity building workshops to parliamentarians held. Output 4.1: 1- No training of a leadership team. 2- No enforcement priorities and no existing plan. Output 4.2: - No existing Labour inspection assessment Output 4.3: - No action plan Output 4.4: - No action plan Output 4.5: - No existing national OSH profile. Output 4.6: - Not enough training of inspectors on OSH. Output 4.7: - No technical capacity of inspectors for monitoring environmental pollutants in the workplace Output 4.8: - weak capacity of employers’ and workers’ representatives on LI and OSH. Output 4.9: - No existing tools. Output 5.1: - No team assembled for the data gathering - No database for gathering and storing data - No data analyzed in graphical form - No data analyzed from month to month Output 5.2: - No database for gathering and storing data - No process for reporting formulated at PAM -No reporting team established Output 5.3: - No training conducted on PAM staff to create, and produce the reports - No training conducted for remaining PAM staff to understand and analyze reports.

target.comment: Output 1: Programme management unit established and functional Output 2: - Appropriate staff, PAM focal point, and consultants in place, and steering committee established; - Three comprehensive research reports and three dissemination workshops contribute to evidence-based decisions in PAM; - PAM authorities officially recognize value of research and support ongoing research to inform policy development; - % of workshop participants acknowledging greater understanding of non-market drivers and able to implement knowledge in their day-to-day work; - PAM evaluates and implements at least five of the recommendations to better align labour mobility management structures with economic development objectives. -Shelter report issued - PAM staff trained on shelter management- 50 - Study tour to share best practices- 1 - Technical roundtable- 1 - Pre & post feasibility assessment on AVRR- 2 - Migrants provided with AVRR- 75 Output 3: - At least 8 Government, 8 Employers and 8 Workers representatives participated in a Standards training course in the ILO Training Centre in Turin. - At least one workshop held on the ratification and application of conventions 100, 111, 122, 129,187, and 189. - Three trainers of the Kuwait Institute for Judicial Studies, and 5 judges from Kuwait, 2 from each of other GCC countries trained in an interregional activity for judges and lawyers in the ILO Training Centre in Turin. - At least 1 capacity building workshops held on ILS implementation for parliamentarians. Output 4: - A leadership team of employees of Public Authority of Manpower trained. - Needed Enforcement Priorities established and enforcement Plan developed for 24 month period. - Assessment and recommendations completed. - Action Plan developed based on Assessment and in support of Enforcement Plan. - 75% of Enforcement Plan implemented. - OSH Profile implemented by PAM. - All PAM inspectors trained on basic OSH and risk assessment. - At least six OSH specialists including wom

actual.comment: Project has initiated by mid 2015 even it was signed by January 2015. It has partially delays in its activities but it is on track currently; the following results have been achieved in 2015: - UNDP Project Associate and Manager were hired in the last quarter of 2015. - PAM team has been identified and a PSO office has been established to work on development projects - Selection of project assistants, manager, and required technical consultants is finalized. - IOM launched a TOR and a Call for Proposal and has selected research consultants for two selected corridors to Kuwait - Participation of two government representatives in a standard training course in Turin in May 2015 and another two November 2015.

iati-activity.title: ICDI / KNDP
iati-activity.description: The ICDI/KNDP project seeks to provide a framework of technical support to GSSCPD and CSB and other public entities to create an enabling environment for implementation, monitoring and evaluation and ultimately delivery of KNDP results.

iati-activity.description: The ICDI/KNDP project seeks to provide a framework of technical support to GSSCPD and CSB and other public entities to create an enabling environment for implementation, monitoring and evaluation and ultimately delivery of KNDP results.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Percentage of implementation of the National Development Plan

baseline.comment: New National Development Plan (2015-2018 -- implementation beginning 1 Sept 2015)

target.comment: Technical support to the restructuring and upgrading of the public administration at the GSSCPD producing an implementation plan for strategic reorganization. Upgrade GSSCPD monitoring and evaluation mechanisms for implementation of KNDP Establishmet of a consultancy roster for functional and technical advisory services that applies a an on-going assessment of productivity for service delivery Develop and enhance statistical foundation for new KNDP indicators Provision of demand-based recruitment of technical experts for public entities

actual.comment: Creation of a Human Resources Strategy 2015-2025 for GSSCPD, informed by the institutional skills audit with an HR database, executive plan, SOPs and a staff capacity development plan (skills) Creation of an effective M&E mechanism based on an assessment, gaps analysis that includes necessary database, systems or tools Delivery of the action plan with development of 12 generic profiles as a first stage for the establishment of a consultancy roster Technical support through Experts to the development of the CSB 1. indicators; 2.sampling and survey techniques;3.assess and monitor KOPSII;4.International/Foreign Trade;5.Labour Market Statistics for National indicators for economic development Technical Experts were provided to the following national entities to assist in developing sectorial plans linked to the NMRDP.
